response:
A young man with isolated unilateral optic neuropathy is most likely to have demyelinating optic neuritis, often associated with multiple sclerosis; however, Raynaud’s phenomenon and a chest radiograph abnormality enlarge the differential to include neuromyelitis optica, MOG-antibody disease, sarcoidosis and other autoimmune or vasculitic optic neuropathies, while ischaemic, compressive, retinal and infectious causes remain important but less likely.

differential_diagnosis = ["Demyelinating optic neuritis (clinically isolated syndrome suggestive of multiple sclerosis)", "Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (AQP4-IgG\u2013associated)", "Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) presenting with optic neuritis", "Sarcoid-associated optic neuropathy (neurosarcoidosis)", "Autoimmune or vasculitic optic neuropathy (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, ANCA-associated vasculitis, mixed connective tissue disease)", "Non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy", "Compressive optic neuropathy (e.g., optic nerve sheath meningioma, orbital mass)", "Retinal pathology causing central scotoma (e.g., macular disease, central serous chorioretinopathy)", "Infectious optic neuropathy (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis, Lyme disease, viral)"]
